A researcher will conduct a study to investigate whether a certain ear drop is effective in relieving swimmer’s ear (an infection of the outer ear canal). Two design options are proposed. Option A Option B Randomly select <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people from the population of people who have swimmer’s ear to use the ear drop each day. Observe the number of people who experience relief after two weeks. Obtain <math alttext="80" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers from the population of people with swimmer’s ear. Randomly assign <math alttext="30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use the ear drop each day and <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people to a group to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people who experience relief in each group after two weeks. (a) If the researcher were to choose Option A, describe, in the context of the study, a statistical reason for using stratified random sampling instead of simple random sampling in this design.

(b) The researcher is considering using an alternate design: a matched-pairs design. Explain a benefit that a matched-pairs design would bring to the investigation and identify a characteristic that can be used to group the <math alttext="80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> people into pairs.

The researcher conducted the study using the design described in Option B. The results of the study are shown in the following bar graph. (c) Suppose one person is randomly selected from each group (Ear Drop and Placebo) in the study. A student claims that the likelihood of selecting a person who experienced relief is greater for the Placebo group than for the Ear Drop group because the total number of people who experienced relief in the study is greater for the Placebo group than for the Ear Drop group. Explain the error in the student’s claim.

The researcher will use the sample data to complete a hypothesis test to investigate the following research question. Is there a difference between use of the ear drop and use of the placebo in the relief experienced from swimmer’s ear? Let <math alttext="p sub E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who experience relief using the ear drop, and let <math alttext="p sub P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who experience relief using a placebo. The hypotheses of the test used by the researcher are as follows. <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub E equals p sub P. H sub a: P sub E is not equal to p sub P." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) Describe, in the context of the study, the consequence of a Type <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> error for the test.

The conditions for inference have been met. A <math alttext="94%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>94</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> confidence interval to estimate <math alttext="p sub E minus p sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="negative 0.15 comma 0.27" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.15</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mn>0.27</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(e) Based on the confidence interval, how should the researcher answer the research question? Explain your answer.
